factoid: Dólokhov said 'I should not be doing my duty, Count.'
Dólokhov said the statement in timid tones.
Dólokhov said 'I should not justify your confidence, Count, in the way I have done.'
Dólokhov said 'I think there is no sufficient ground for this affair to continue.'
Dólokhov said 'You were not right, Count, in the way you have behaved.'
Pierre said 'Oh yes, it is horribly stupid.'
Pierre said 'Then allow me to express your regrets, and I am sure your opponent will accept them.'
Nesvítski said 'You know, Count, it is much more honorable to admit one's mistake than to continue to argue.'
Nesvítski said 'There was no insult on either side.'
Pierre said 'No! What is there to talk about?'
Pierre said 'It’s all the same.'
Pierre said 'Is everything ready?'
Pierre said 'Only tell me where to go and where to shoot.'
Pierre had an unnaturally gentle smile.
Pierre took the pistol in his hand.
Pierre began asking about the working of the trigger.
Pierre had not before held a pistol in his hand.
Pierre did not wish to confess that Pierre had never held a pistol before.
Pierre said 'Oh yes, like that, I know, I only forgot.'
Dólokhov said 'No apologies, none whatever.'
Dólokhov said 'No apologies, none whatever' to Denísov.
Dólokhov also went up to the appointed place.
The battlefield was a flat plain with a few scattered trees.
The trees were located at the edge of the plain.
The trees were at the boundary of the plain.
The trees were at the edge of the plain.
The trees were at the boundary of the plain.
The trees were located at the edge of the plain.
Dólokhov and Pierre stood forty paces apart at the farther edge of the clearing.
The seconds measured the paces.
The seconds left tracks in the deep wet snow between the place where they had been standing and Nesvítski’s and Dólokhov’s sabers.
Nesvítski’s and Dólokhov’s sabers were stuck into the ground ten paces apart to mark the barrier.
It was thawing and misty.
At forty paces distance nothing could be seen.
For three minutes Dólokhov and Pierre had been ready, but Dólokhov and Pierre still delayed and all were silent.
Dólokhov said 'Well, begin!'
Pierre said 'All right.'
A feeling of dread was in the air.
It was evident that the affair so lightly begun could no longer be averted but was taking its course independently of men’s will.
Denísov first went to the barrier and announced that Dólokhov and Pierre should proceed and take their pistols.
Denísov shouted 'O-ne! T-wo! Thwee!'.
Dólokhov and Pierre advanced along the trodden tracks, nearer and nearer to one another.
Dólokhov and Pierre began to see one another through the mist.
Dólokhov and Pierre had the right to fire when they liked as they approached the barrier.
Dólokhov walked slowly without raising his pistol.
Dólokhov looked intently with his bright, sparkling blue eyes into Pierre’s face.
Dólokhov’s mouth wore his usual semblance of a smile.
Pierre said 'So I can fire when I like!'.
At the word 'three,' Pierre went quickly forward.
Pierre missed the trodden path and stepped into the deep snow.
Pierre held the pistol in his right hand at arm’s length.
Pierre was apparently afraid of shooting himself with the pistol.
Pierre held his left hand carefully back.
Pierre wanted to support his right hand with his left hand.
Pierre knew he must not do so.
Pierre advanced six paces and strayed off the track into the snow.
Pierre looked down at his feet.
Pierre glanced at Dólokhov.
Pierre bent his finger as he had been shown.
Pierre fired.
Pierre did not expect a loud report.
Pierre shuddered at the sound.
Pierre smiled at his own sensations.
Pierre stood still.
The smoke was rendered denser by the mist.
The smoke prevented Pierre from seeing anything for an instant.
There was no second report as Pierre had expected.
Pierre only heard Dólokhov’s hurried steps.
Dólokhov’s figure came in view through the smoke.
Dólokhov was pressing one hand to his left side.
Dólokhov's other hand clutched his drooping pistol.
Dólokhov’s face was pale.
Rostóv ran toward Dólokhov.
Rostóv said something.
